qas.question: Is textual criticism immune to bias on the part of the critic?

answers.text: justify a result that fits the textual critic's aesthetic or theological agenda

qas.question: When did scientists begin searching for a more defined guideline for textual criticism?
What inclusion helps readers and critics understand the motivation behind the compiler?

answers.text: The citing of sources used, and alternate readings, and the use of original text and images

qas.question: What is a further benefit of including sources, texts and original images in a critique?

answers.text: the depth of research of the critic

qas.question: What canons are not susceptible to interpretation?
When did scholars stop looking for more rigorous methods?

plausible_answers.text: establishing one or a few witnesses presumably as being favored by "objective" criteria

qas.question: The editor sought to raise subjectivity by what?
Who was only permitted to select one reading?

context: Since the canons of <b4_0><b5_0>criticism<b5_0/><b4_0/> are highly susceptible to interpretation, and at times even contradict each other, they may be employed to <a0_0>justify a result that fits the textual critic's aesthetic or theological agenda<a0_0/>. Starting in the <a1_0><b6_0>19th century<b6_0/><a1_0/>, scholars sought more rigorous methods to guide editorial judgment. Best-text editing (a complete rejection of eclecticism) became one extreme. Stemmatics and copy-text editing – while both eclectic, in that they permit <b8_0>the editor<b8_0/> to select readings from multiple sources – sought to reduce subjectivity by <b7_0>establishing one or a few witnesses presumably as being favored by "objective" criteria<b7_0/>.[citation needed] <a2_0>The citing of sources used, and alternate readings, and the use of original text and images<a2_0/> helps readers and other critics determine to an extent <a3_0>the depth of research of the critic<a3_0/>, and to independently verify their work.
